sections.title: Introduction to Systematic Debugging
sections.content: Effective debugging is not just about finding bugsâ€”it's about developing a systematic approach to problem-solving. In FTC development, you need strategies that work both in the lab and under competition pressure. This lesson teaches you how to approach debugging methodically and efficiently.

sections.title: Why Systematic Debugging Matters
items: FTC competitions have limited time for debugging and testing
Hardware-software interactions create complex failure modes
Systematic approaches prevent you from making the same mistakes
Good debugging skills transfer to other programming domains
Competition environments require quick problem resolution

sections.title: The Scientific Method of Debugging
sections.content: Apply the scientific method to debugging: observe the problem, form a hypothesis, test it, and refine your understanding. This systematic approach helps you avoid random trial-and-error debugging.

sections.title: Debugging Framework - Core Structure
sections.content: Implement a structured debugging process in your code. This framework provides a systematic approach to debugging by following the scientific method. The framework tracks observations, hypotheses, tests, and conclusions:

sections.title: Understanding the Scientific Method in Debugging
sections.content: The scientific method provides a systematic approach to debugging. First, you observe and document the problem with specific data. Then you form a hypothesis about what might be causing the issue. This structured approach prevents random trial-and-error debugging.

sections.title: Debugging Framework - Testing and Conclusion Methods
sections.content: Add methods for testing hypotheses and documenting conclusions. These methods complete the scientific method cycle by testing your hypothesis and recording the results:

sections.title: Completing the Debugging Cycle
sections.content: The testing and conclusion methods complete the debugging cycle. Testing verifies whether your hypothesis was correct, and conclusions document what you learned and what steps to take next. This creates a record that helps with future debugging and team communication.

sections.title: Common FTC Debugging Scenarios
sections.content: FTC development has specific challenges that require targeted debugging strategies. Understanding these common scenarios helps you develop effective debugging approaches.

sections.title: Hardware Debugger - Basic Structure

sections.title: Understanding Hardware Debugging
sections.content: The hardware debugger systematically tests each component of the motor connection. First, it checks if the motor exists in the hardware map. Then it tests if the motor responds to basic commands. This helps identify whether the issue is configuration, wiring, or software-related.

sections.title: Understanding Sensor Debugging
sections.content: The sensor debugging method first checks if the sensor exists in the hardware map, then calls specific debugging methods based on the sensor type. This allows for customized testing for each type of sensor.

sections.title: Hardware Debugger - Specific Sensor Debug Methods
sections.content: Add specific debugging methods for different sensor types. Each method tests the sensor's basic functionality:

sections.title: Understanding Sensor-Specific Debugging
sections.content: Each sensor type has different testing requirements. Color sensors need to read RGB values, and distance sensors need to return distance measurements. These specific methods ensure each sensor type is tested appropriately.

sections.title: State Machine Debugging
sections.content: State machines are common in FTC autonomous programs but can be difficult to debug. Use systematic approaches to track state transitions and identify issues.

sections.title: Debuggable State Machine - Core Structure
sections.content: Create a debuggable state machine that tracks transitions and conditions. This class provides comprehensive debugging information for state machines:

sections.title: Understanding State Machine Debugging
sections.content: The debuggable state machine tracks the current state, previous state, and how long each state has been active. It automatically detects when a state has been active too long, which often indicates a bug in the transition logic.

sections.title: Debuggable State Machine - Transition and History Methods
sections.content: Add methods for managing state transitions and tracking history:

sections.title: Understanding State Transitions
sections.content: The transitionTo method records every state change with the reason for the transition and how long the previous state was active. This creates a complete history that helps identify patterns in state machine behavior.

sections.title: Understanding State Machine Display
sections.content: The debugStateMachine method displays comprehensive information about the state machine's current status and recent history. The StateTransition helper class stores all the details about each state change for analysis.

sections.title: Performance Debugging
sections.content: Performance issues in FTC can cause missed commands, laggy telemetry, or unreliable autonomous behavior. Learn to identify and fix performance bottlenecks.

sections.title: Performance Monitor - Core Structure
sections.content: Create a framework to monitor and debug performance issues. This class tracks loop timing and operation performance:

sections.title: Understanding Performance Monitoring
sections.content: The performance monitor tracks how long each loop takes to execute. It calculates the average and maximum loop times, and alerts you when loops take too long. This helps identify performance bottlenecks in your code.

sections.title: Performance Monitor - Operation Tracking Methods
sections.content: Add methods for tracking individual operation performance:

sections.title: Understanding Operation Tracking
sections.content: The operation tracking methods allow you to measure how long specific operations take. You can wrap any code section with startOperation() and endOperation() calls to identify which parts of your code are causing performance issues.

sections.title: Performance Monitor - Analysis and Reporting
sections.content: Add methods for analyzing and reporting performance data:

sections.title: Understanding Performance Analysis
sections.content: The analyzePerformance method provides detailed statistics about your code's performance. It shows average and maximum loop times, and breaks down the performance of individual operations. This helps you identify which parts of your code need optimization.

sections.title: Competition Debugging Strategies
sections.content: Competition environments require different debugging strategies. You have limited time and need to work quickly and efficiently.

sections.title: Competition Debugging Checklist
items: Have a pre-competition debugging checklist ready
Use quick diagnostic tools that provide immediate feedback
Keep debugging logs concise but informative
Have backup strategies for common failure modes
Practice debugging under time pressure before competition
Document successful debugging approaches for future reference

sections.title: Understanding Competition Debugging
sections.content: The competition debugger provides quick, essential diagnostics that can be run rapidly during competition. It focuses on the most critical hardware components and provides immediate feedback about their status.

sections.content: The monitoring methods help track critical values during competition. The monitorValue method highlights when values change, making it easy to spot unexpected behavior. answers.task: Implement the scientific method debugging framework
Add performance monitoring to identify bottlenecks
Write a debugging checklist for common failure modes
answers.content:
// Example checklist:
1. Verify all hardware is configured correctly in the configuration file.
2. Run quick hardware check before each match.
3. Check sensor readings in telemetry before starting.
4. Use debug logs to confirm state transitions.
5. Monitor loop timing for performance issues.
6. Have a backup plan for hardware failures (e.g., swap motors, sensors).
7. Document any issues and solutions for future reference.

answers.task: Practice debugging the system with intentional bugs
Document your debugging process and findings
answers.content:
// Example documentation:
- Observed that the robot did not approach the object long enough.
- Hypothesized that the time threshold was too short.
- Set a conditional breakpoint on the approach state.
- Confirmed that the transition occurred at 0.5s instead of 2.0s.
- Fixed the bug by changing the threshold to 2.0.
- Verified correct behavior with logs and telemetry.
- Added this scenario to the debugging checklist for future reference.
